statement: Jan 27-28 FOMC: market pricing skewed to no-change (~88.5% per Polymarket snapshot).
market_link: Front-end (ZT/ZF) and equity duration (ES/NQ) are sensitive to data/speakers shifting near-term policy odds.

statement: Fed calendar: Jan 28 FOMC decision 2:00pm ET; press conference 2:30pm ET.
market_link: Known timing concentrates intraday volatility around statement/presser across ES/NQ and the Treasury complex.

statement: NY Fed SRF usage hit record $74.6B on Dec 31 amid year-end funding needs (Reuters).
market_link: Turn-of-year funding dynamics matter for front-end rates; focus is whether take-up normalizes post-turn.

statement: NY Fed: standing overnight repo ops moved to full allotment with no aggregate operational limit (eff. Dec 11).
market_link: Structural tool-setting that can cap tail repo spikes; becomes relevant when funding-stress headlines hit.

statement: Eurozone Dec final mfg PMI 48.8; Germany final 47.0 with export demand a key drag (Reuters).
market_link: EU growth softness can pressure risk tone and support UST duration; also relevant for EUR (6E) and USD (DX).

statement: US cash close (Jan 2): MOC buy imbalance S&P +1485.3M; NQ +330.8M; Dow +432.2M; Mag7 +273.3M.
market_link: Large closing imbalances can drive late-day futures dislocations and raise next-session gap sensitivity in ES/NQ.

statement: Eurozone M3 y/y 3.0% (Nov) vs 2.8% (Oct); slow-moving liquidity signal.
market_link: Secondary input for EUR rates/FX; matters for US futures mainly via EU risk/ECB repricing headlines.

statement: US S&P Global final mfg PMI confirmed 51.8 for Dec; no revision vs prior/forecast.
market_link: Final print tends to be lower impact than ISM; attention usually on prices/new orders details vs an unchanged headline.

statement: UK Dec final mfg PMI 50.6 vs flash 51.2; marginal expansion but softer than first read.
market_link: UK/Europe growth tone can influence broad risk sentiment; usually modest direct impact on US index futures.
